Small trees in supercritical random forests

Tao Lei Department of Mathematics and Statistics, McGill University, 805 Sherbrooke Street West, MontrÃ©al, QuÃ©bec, H3A 0B9, Canada tao.lei@mail.mcgill.ca http://www.math.mcgill.ca/âˆ¼similar-to\simtlei/
(Date: October 5, 2017)
Abstract.

We study the scaling limit of random forest with prescribed degree sequence in the regime that the largest tree consists of all but a vanishing fraction of nodes. We give a description of the limit of the forest consisting of the small trees, by relating plane forest to marked cyclic forest and its corresponding lattice path.

Key words and phrases:
Random forests, continuum random trees, degree sequence, GHP convergence.
1991 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary: 60C05. Secondary: 05C05,05C80

1. Introduction

A plane tree is a finite rooted tree in which the children of each node are ordered. A plane forest is a finite sequence of plane trees.

More precisely, writing câ€‹(s):=âˆ‘iâ‰¥0(1âˆ’i)â€‹si>0assignğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘–01ğ‘–superscriptğ‘ ğ‘–0c(s):=\sum\limits_{i\geq 0}(1-i)s^{i}>0, then any forest with degree sequence sğ‘ s consists of exactly câ€‹(s)ğ‘ğ‘ c(s) trees.

The goal of this paper is to study the asymptotic structure of large random forests with a given degree sequence, in the â€œsupercriticalâ€, finite variance regime. In this setting, the forest typically consists of a single, large tree containing all but a vanishing fraction of the nodes. The scaling limit of this tree is ğ’¯ğ’¯{\mathcal{T}}, the Brownian Continuum Random Tree (CRT) introduced by Aldous in [2, 3, 4]. The remaining nodes form another random forest, which may be expected to have its own scaling limit (with an appropriate rescaling, which should be different from that of the large tree). The contributions of this paper confirm that the above picture is correct, and yield a pleasingly straightforward description, which we now provide, for the joint scaling limit of the large tree and the small trees.

Remarks.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet The condition that âˆ‘iâ‰¥0sni=nsubscriptğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›\sum_{i\geq 0}s_{n}^{i}=n in TheoremÂ 1.1 is for notational convenience; all proofs carry through with only cosmetic changes provided that |sn|=âˆ‘iâ‰¥0sniâ†’âˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘–â†’|s_{n}|=\sum_{i\geq 0}s_{n}^{i}\to\infty as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty, that |sn|âˆ’1â‹…snâ†’pâ†’â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘|s_{n}|^{-1}\cdot s_{n}\to p in L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} and that cn=oâ€‹(|sn|1/2)subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›12c_{n}=o(|s_{n}|^{1/2}).
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Fix a critical, finite variance offspring distribution Î½ğœˆ\nu, and let â„±nsubscriptâ„±ğ‘›\mathcal{F}_{n} be a forest of cnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›c_{n} independent Galton-Watson(Î½)ğœˆ(\nu) trees with offspring distribution Î½ğœˆ\nu, conditioned to have total progeny nğ‘›n. It is not hard to check, as in [6], that with high probability the degree sequence of â„±nsubscriptâ„±ğ‘›\mathcal{F}_{n} satisfies the conditions of TheoremÂ 1.1, so the distributional convergence of the theorem also applies to â„±nsubscriptâ„±ğ‘›\mathcal{F}_{n}. The convergence of the third coordinate, in the Galton-Watson setting, appears as TheoremÂ 2.1.5 of [15], and provides a new proof and different perspective on that result; the convergence of the second coordinate strengthens and generalizes and removes a moment assumption from TheoremÂ 1.7 of [7].

The field of scaling limit of large random structures is motivated by the seminal papers [2, 3, 4] by Aldous, where he introduced the concept of Brownian Continuum Random Tree and showed that critical Galton-Watson tree conditioned on its size has CRT as limiting object. To be more specific, our work here is a natural generalization of [6] where it is shown that under natural hypotheses on the degree sequences, after suitable normalization, uniformly random trees with given degree sequence converge to CRT as sizes of trees tend to infinity. Let nğ‘›n be the number of nodes of the forest. In this paper we work on uniformly random forests where the number of trees is oâ€‹(n1/2)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›12o(n^{1/2}); a previous paper [12] addressed the asymptotic behaviour of such forests in the regime where the number of trees is of order n1/2superscriptğ‘›12n^{1/2}.

Outline of the section

In the remainder of this section, we first briefly introduce the concepts required to understand the statement of Theorem 1.1 rigorously. In SectionÂ 1.2 we describe the key ingredients of the proof of our main theorem. In Section 1.3 we explain how to deduce Theorem 1.1 from the results of SectionÂ 1.2, and outline the remaining sections of the article.

1.1. Concepts

Real trees

We briefly recall the concepts of real trees and real trees coded by continuous functions, which are necessary for understanding the construction of â„±â„±\mathcal{F}. A more lengthy presentation about the probabilistic aspects of real trees can be found in [10, 11].

Definition 1.2.

A compact metric space (T,d)ğ‘‡ğ‘‘(T,d) is a real tree if the following hold for every a,bâˆˆTğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‡a,b\in T:

Outline of the rest of the paper

In Section 2 we describe a combinatorial construction which associates a marked cyclic forest with the concatenation of a sequence of first passage bridges, followed by one lattice bridge. This construction is what links Theorem 1.4 with random forests. In Section 3 we give the proof of Theorem 1.4 and Corollary 1.5. Finally in Section 4 we prove (1.4) and (1.5) using martingale concentration inequalities.

2. Coding marked forests by lattice paths

We call a sequence of integers ğ›=(bâ€‹(0),bâ€‹(1),â€¦,bâ€‹(n))ğ›ğ‘0ğ‘1â€¦ğ‘ğ‘›\mathbf{b}=(b(0),b(1),\ldots,b(n)) a lattice bridge if

bâ€‹(0)=0,bâ€‹(n)=âˆ’1â€‹Â andÂ â€‹âˆ€0â‰¤iâ‰¤nâˆ’1,bâ€‹(i+1)âˆ’bâ€‹(i)â‰¥âˆ’1.formulae-sequenceformulae-sequenceğ‘00ğ‘ğ‘›1Â andÂ for-all0ğ‘–ğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘–1b(0)=0,b(n)=-1\mbox{ and }\forall 0\leq i\leq n-1,~{}b(i+1)-b(i)\geq-1.

If ğ›ğ›\mathbf{b} is a lattice bridge and miniâ¡{i:bâ€‹(i)=âˆ’1}=nsubscriptğ‘–:ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘›\min\limits_{i}\{i:b(i)=-1\}=n, then we call ğ›ğ›\mathbf{b} a first passage bridge. Given a lattice bridge ğ›ğ›\mathbf{b} and a positive integer kâ‰¤nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\leq n, we define a lattice bridge ğ›(k)superscriptğ›ğ‘˜\mathbf{b}^{(k)} as follows. First, for 1â‰¤iâ‰¤n1ğ‘–ğ‘›1\leq i\leq n, let bâ€‹(n+i)=bâ€‹(n)+bâ€‹(i)=âˆ’1+bâ€‹(i)ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘–b(n+i)=b(n)+b(i)=-1+b(i). Then for 0â‰¤iâ‰¤n0ğ‘–ğ‘›0\leq i\leq n, let ğ›(k)â€‹(i)=bâ€‹(k+i)âˆ’bâ€‹(k)superscriptğ›ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘˜\mathbf{b}^{(k)}(i)=b(k+i)-b(k). Let [n]={1,â‹¯,n}delimited-[]ğ‘›1â‹¯ğ‘›[n]=\{1,\cdots,n\}. We have the following elementary lemma as a variant of the classical ballot theorem.

Lemma 2.1 (Lemma 6.1 in [16]).

Fix a lattice bridge ğ›=(bâ€‹(i),0â‰¤iâ‰¤n)ğ›ğ‘ğ‘–0ğ‘–ğ‘›\mathbf{b}=(b(i),0\leq i\leq n), and let r=râ€‹(ğ›)âˆˆ[n]ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ›delimited-[]ğ‘›r=r(\mathbf{b})\in[n] be minimal so that bâ€‹(r)=minâ¡(bâ€‹(i),iâ‰¤n)ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘›b(r)=\min(b(i),i\leq n). Lemma 2.1 is illustrated by Figure 2.1(a) and Figure 2.1(b). In Figure 2.1(a) we have a lattice bridge ğ›=(0,âˆ’1,âˆ’1,âˆ’2,âˆ’1,1,0,âˆ’1)ğ›01121101\mathbf{b}=(0,-1,-1,-2,-1,1,0,-1). The vertical dashed line shows the position of ğ›ğ›\mathbf{b} attaining its minimum for the first time, hence the unique position for the cyclic shift to transform ğ›ğ›\mathbf{b} to a first passage bridge, as claimed by Lemma 2.1. The resulting first lattice bridge, with steps ğ›(3)superscriptğ›3\mathbf{b}^{(3)}, is shown in Figure 2.1(b).

A plane tree is a rooted tree Tğ‘‡T in which the children of each node have a left-to-right order.
